Excellent point. Fortunately for me, granularity is not an issue because I
am mutating the entire execution context.

This brings up a question that I've been pondering: Given a test T, which of
the following two choices is more desirable?
   o Enable profiling for T by specifying some preference and let the
execution framework do the rest.
   o Enable profiling for T by coding a new test Tp that decorates T with
profiling. When you want to run T with profiling you run Tp. When you want
to run T without it you just run T. This is very similar to the way
JUnitPerf works.

Mike Clark Wrote:
>
> Michael Silverstein wrote:
>
> >
> > Wrapping test execution
> > -----------------------
> > I need to be able to start profiling immediately before a user
> test starts
> > and end profiling immediately afterward. One approach is to
> wrap the user
> > test class that is presently instantiated in
> > junit.runner.BaseTestRunner.getTest(String) with a
> TestDecorator subclass
> > instance that manages profiling during test execution. Creating the
> > decorator sounds like a job for factory method [Gamma95].
>
> JUnitPerf attempts to something similar - start a timer
> immediately before the
> test executes and stop the timer immediately after the test
> completes.  However,
> the granularity of test decoration offered by the TestDecorator
> includes the
> time associated with setting up and tearing down the test
> fixture.  In other
> words, decorating the Test.run() method includes the overhead of
> setUp() and
> tearDown().
>
> I'm not sure how you're defining profiling, but I wanted to make
> you were aware
> of the implications of decoration and how it relates to the life
> cycle of test
> execution.
>
> Mike
